You said:
There are two Mexican chili powders on the right. Given these, and my desire to cook a half leg of lamb in my pressure cooker, what are some recipes involving these spices, lamb, and my pressure cooker?
ChatGPT said:
Request for GPT-5 Pro
Reasoned for 5m 31s

Fantastic—Mexican chile powders + lamb + a pressure cooker is a winning combo.
Below are four solid options that lean on the two Mexican chile powders you mentioned (use one for deep, earthy sweetness—e.g., ancho/pasilla—and the other for heat—e.g., chipotle/árbol). I’ve written them for a half leg of lamb, bone‑in (about 1.5–2.2 kg) and for your pantry items from the photos (bay leaves, Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend, white pepper, chili oil, honey‑sriracha, etc.).

0) Quick reference: pressure times

  • Shreddable (barbacoa/birria): 65–75 min on High Pressure + 15 min natural release.

  • Sliceable/roast‑like: 35–40 min on High Pressure + 10 min natural release.
    Use 1–1½ cups total liquid in the pot (stock/water/juice + anything in your marinade). Always rest 10 min before carving or shredding.

Salt guide: ~2–2½ tsp kosher/sea salt for a 1.5–2 kg leg (adjust to taste).

1) Pressure‑Cooker Lamb Barbacoa (shreddable tacos, bowls, or sandwiches)

You’ll use: both Mexican chile powders, Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend (or your dhana‑jeera), bay leaves, white pepper, chili oil.
Optional finish: brush with your Honey Sriracha and broil to crisp.

Ingredients

  • Half leg of lamb, bone‑in

  • 2 Tbsp mild Mexican chile powder (e.g., ancho/pasilla)

  • 1 Tbsp hot Mexican chile powder (e.g., chipotle/árbol)

  • 2 tsp Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend (or 1 tsp ground cumin + 1 tsp ground coriander)

  • 2–2½ tsp salt, ½ tsp white pepper

  • 4 cloves garlic, crushed (or 1 tsp garlic powder)

  • 2 Tbsp apple‑cider or white vinegar

  • 1 Tbsp brown sugar or honey

  • 1–2 Tbsp chili oil (for searing and the paste)

  • 1 cup stock or water

  • 2 bay leaves

Method

  1. Paste: Mix chile powders, spice blend, salt, pepper, garlic, vinegar, sugar/honey and a spoon of chili oil with enough water to make a loose paste.

  2. Sear (optional but great): Pat lamb dry, score the fat, heat chili oil on Sauté and brown well.

  3. Pressure cook: Add the paste, 1 cup stock/water and bay leaves. Coat the lamb, lock the lid, cook 65–75 min High Pressure, 15 min natural release.

  4. Shred & crisp: Remove lamb, shred. Strain some liquid, skim fat. Toss meat with a little cooking liquid. For crispy edges, spread on a tray and broil/grill 5–8 min, optionally brushing with Honey Sriracha in the last minute.

  5. Serve: tacos, rice bowls, burritos, or on flatbreads. Use the strained jus as a dipping consomé.

2) Birria‑Style Lamb (for tacos or “birria ramen”)

You’ll use: both Mexican chile powders, Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend, bay leaves, white pepper.
Optional: a tiny pinch of your Christmas pudding/cake spice mimics the traditional warm notes (cinnamon/clove)—use ⅛ tsp max.

Ingredients

  • Same lamb + base as Barbacoa, plus:

  • 2 Tbsp tomato paste (or 1 large tomato, chopped)

  • 1 Tbsp vinegar plus ½ cup orange juice or water

  • ½ tsp dried oregano (if not in your Mexican blend)

  • Optional: tiny pinch “Christmas” spice

Method

  1. Blend chile powders, spice blend, tomato paste, vinegar, juice/water, oregano, salt, white pepper, optional warm spice.

  2. Sear lamb (optional). Add marinade, ½–1 cup extra water if needed to reach ~1½ cups liquid total, and 2 bay leaves.

  3. Pressure 55–70 min, 15–20 min natural release (shorter end for sliceable, longer for shreddable).

  4. Shred/cube. Skim fat from the broth.

  5. To serve:

    • Quesa‑birria tacos: dip tortillas in the broth fat, griddle with cheese + meat, serve with the consomé.

    • Birria ramen: cook noodles, add some Ramen Seasoning to taste, ladle in birria broth and meat.

3) Adobo‑Rubbed Leg with Honey‑Sriracha Glaze (sliceable, roast‑like)

You’ll use: both Mexican chile powders, Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend (or cumin/coriander), white pepper, Wasabi‑Pepper mustard (as a binder; you won’t taste wasabi), Honey Sriracha to glaze.

Ingredients

  • 1½ Tbsp mild Mexican chile powder

  • 1 tsp hot Mexican chile powder (more for heat)

  • 2 tsp Mexican Spice Blend (or 1 tsp cumin + 1 tsp coriander)

  • 2–2½ tsp salt, ½ tsp white pepper

  • 2 tsp Wasabi‑Pepper mustard (binder)

  • 1–2 Tbsp chili oil

  • 1 cup stock/water + 2 bay leaves

  • 3–4 Tbsp Honey Sriracha (finish)

Method

  1. Mix chile powders, spice blend, salt and pepper. Rub lamb with mustard, then the spice mix.

  2. Sear in chili oil. Add 1 cup liquid + bay leaves.

  3. Pressure 35–40 min High for sliceable medium, 10 min natural release.

  4. Brush with Honey Sriracha, then broil/grill 5–8 min to lacquer the surface. Rest 10 min before carving.

4) Chile Colorado‑ish Lamb Stew (if you cut the leg into chunks)

You’ll use: both Mexican chile powders, Herbie’s Mexican Spice Blend, white pepper, bay leaves.
This makes a deep red stew great over rice or with flatbreads.

Ingredients

  • 1.2–1.5 kg lamb leg meat, 4–5 cm chunks

  • 1½ Tbsp mild chile powder + 2–3 tsp hot chile powder

  • 2 tsp Mexican Spice Blend (or cumin/coriander)

  • 2 tsp salt, ½ tsp white pepper

  • 1 onion (sliced) & 3 cloves garlic (optional but nice)

  • 1 Tbsp tomato paste (optional)

  • 1½ cups stock/water, 2 bay leaves

  • Optional add‑ins from your pantry: a pinch fenugreek leaves for a subtle maple note; Kashmiri chili for extra color without much extra heat.

Method

  1. Sauté onion/garlic, bloom chile powders & spice blend 30–60 sec, stir in tomato paste.

  2. Add lamb, salt/pepper, liquid, bay leaves (and optional fenugreek/Kashmiri).

  3. Pressure 25–30 min High, 10 min natural release.

  4. Reduce sauce on Sauté to thicken; season with a splash of vinegar and a little honey if desired.

Tips to use what you have

  • Chili oil (VomFASS): perfect for searing and blooming the spices.

  • Bay leaves: drop 1–2 into the pot for any of the recipes.

  • White pepper: adds a clean heat—use ¼–½ tsp in the rub/paste.

  • Mexican Spice Blend (Herbie’s): replaces separate cumin/coriander/oregano.

  • Two Mexican chile powders: treat one as the base (earthy/sweet) and the other as the heat dial; a 2:1 ratio is a good start.

  • Honey‑Sriracha BBQ sauce: brush on at the very end for a sweet‑hot glaze; it’s not traditional but it’s delicious.

If you tell me roughly how heavy your half leg is and whether you want shreddable or sliceable, I’ll tailor one of these with exact salt/liquid amounts and a timing target for your specific cut.
